questions.text:
Ventricular action potential sequence order is
A. Opening voltage gated sodium channels
B. Transient outward flow of potassium
C. Opening of voltage gated calcium channels
D. Repolarizing K+ currents
questions.solution:
Phase 0 (Depolarization): When a depolarizing stimulus is applied on the cardiac cell , voltage-gated sodium channels (fast sodium channels) open and permit sodium to rapidly flow into the cell which causes depolarization.

Phase 1 (Initial Repolarization): In this phase there is inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels and transient outward flow of potassium ions through open potassium channels which causes rapid repolarization.

Phase 2 (Plateau): There is opening of slow voltage gated calcium channels. The combination of decreased potassium ion efflux and increased calcium ion influx causes the action potential to plateau.

Phase 3 (Rapid Repolarization): Opening of various potassium channels leads to efflux of potassium ions from the cell resulting in slow repolarization.

Phase 4 (Resting Membrane Potential): Returns to Resting Membrane Potential which averages about-80 to -90 millivolts.

questions.text: The below graph shows the oxygen dissociation curve. The curve marked as A indicates
questions.solution:
Myoglobin is an iron-containing pigment found in skeletal muscle. Though it is similar to Hb in structure, myoglobin binds one molecule of O2 per mole so it lacks cooperative binding.

Its dissociation curve is a rectangular hyperbola rather than a sigmoid curve because its curve is to the left of the hemoglobin curve.

Myoglobin has higher affinity to oxygen than hemoglobin because myoglobin releases oxygen only at low PO2 which leads to leftward shift of the myoglobin oxygen dissociation curve.

Other options:

Option A: When blood is exposed to various drugs and other oxidizing agents in vitro or in vivo, the ferrous iron (Fe2+) that is normally in the molecule is converted to ferric iron (Fe3+), forming methemoglobin. Methemoglobin is darkcolored, and when it is present in large quantities in the circulation, it causes a dusky discoloration of the skin resembling cyanosis.

Option B: CO binds to hemoglobin to form carboxyhemoglobin(HbCO). The binding affinity of CO with Hb is 210 times more than oxygen. CO shifts the OxyHb dissociation curve to the left, which decreases oxygen release to the tissues.

Option C: The γ chains of fetal Hb have less avidity for 2,3-DPG than β chains of adult Hb. Therefore, fetal Hb has higher oxygen affinity. This provides an advantage to the fetus to extract oxygen from maternal blood in the placenta. Fetal Hb shifts the Oxy-Hb dissociation curve to the left.

questions.text: How do you calculate cerebral perfusion pressure?
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure= Mean arterial pressure(MAP) -Intracranial pressure (ICP)

As brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be relatively constant (Monro -Kellie doctrine).

Uncontrolled rise in ICP may be due to head trauma that leads to uncontrolled increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) which causes a compromise in cerebral perfusion pressure leading to cerebral herniation.

Blood flow of the brain depends upon cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).

Normal values:

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) -75-110 mm Hg

Mean arterial pressure (MAP) -90-100 mm Hg

Intracranial pressure (ICP) -5-15 mm Hg

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure volume curve?
questions.solution:
The pressure is zero at a lung volume that corresponds to the volume of gas in the lungs at functional residual capacity (relaxation volume). The functional residual capacity(FRC) is the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath (RV + ERV). The normal value of FRC is about 2.5 L.

Other options:

Option A: The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort is the residual volume(RV). The normal value of RV is about 1.3 L.

Option C: The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing is called the tidal volume (TV). The normal value of a TV is about 500-750 mL.

Option D: The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV is the inspiratory reserve volume (IRV). The normal value of IRV is about 2L.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma:
questions.solution:
Thyroid binding prealbumin which is also known as transthyretin is a carrier protein for thyroid hormone in the bloodstream.

Albumin is a carrier protein and an osmotic regulator which carries hormones, amino acids, steroids, vitamins and fatty acids.

Haptoglobin is responsible for transport of cell-free hemoglobin.

Hemopexin binds to porphyrins particularly to heme for heme recycling.

questions.text: Which among the following organs have the least arterit e pus pressure difference?
questions.solution:
Kidneys have the least arteriovenous pressure difference of 14mL/L. Arteriovenous oxygen difference refers to the amount of oxygen taken up by the tissues from the blood. Greater is the oxygen utilized by the tissues, greater will be the arteriovenous oxygen difference.

Other options:

Option A: Brain has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 62 mL/L.

Option B: Skin has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 25mL/L.

Option C: Liver has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 34mL/L.

choices.text: Binds to both alpha and beta chain

questions.text: How does 2,3 BPG decrease the affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate(2,3-BPG) is found in large amounts in red cells. It is formed from 3-phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via the Embden-Meyerh of pathway.
  • It is a highly charged anion that binds to the β chains of deoxyhemoglobin leading to unloading of oxygen to tissues.
  • One mole of deoxyhemoglobin(Taut form or T form of hemoglobin) binds 1 mol of 2,3-BPG.

Other options:

2,3-BPG does not bind to alpha and gamma chains.

questions.text:
Cardiac output can be calculated from?
a) ECHO
b) Ventilation perfusion scan
c) Thermo dilution
d) Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is defined as the amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per minute. Normal cardiac output in adults is 5-6 lit/min which is approximately 8% of the body weight.

Cardiac output = stroke volume × heart rate

Cardiac output is usually measured by indirect methods which do not require surgery.

Echocardiography is a noninvasive technique in which ultrasonic waves are emitted from a transducer which detects waves reflected from various parts of the heart. Stroke volume is calculated from the velocity of blood flowing into the aorta.

In the thermodilution method, the cold saline is used as the indicator in which a double lumen catheter is used. The change in temperature of the blood is recorded in the pulmonary artery through the thermistor placed in the catheter. The change in temperature is inversely proportional to the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary artery.

Fick's principle can be referred to the amount of a substance taken up by an organ or by the whole body per unit of time equal to the arteriovenous difference of the substance times blood flow.

Other options: Ventilation-perfusion scan can be used to assess pulmonary circulation and cannot be used for the measurement of the cardiac output.

questions.text: Match the following structure with their markers?
questions.solution: Some enzymes are present in certain organelles only. Such specific enzymes are called marker enzymes. After centrifugation, the separated organelles are identified by detection of marker enzymes in the sample.

questions.text: The primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscle during focusing on a near object is?
questions.solution: Contraction of ciliary muscles is mediated by M3 receptors and the second messenger involved is the IP3-DAG pathway.

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialised cells located at?
questions.solution:
• Macula densa cells are modified epithelial cells present at the distal end of thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle (LOH) when it comes in contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles.
  • Macula densa acts as the sensor which monitors the change in ionic composition and rate of flow of the tubular fluid in the lumen of the tubule.
  • It provides an appropriate feedback signal to the renal corpuscle to change the rate of filtration so that it can meet the needs of the kidney functions.

choices.text: Active Na absorption, Passive Cl absorption, Active K secretion, active & passive secretion of HCO3
Passive Na absorption, Passive Cl absorption, Active K secretion, active & passive secretion of HCO3
Active Na absorption, Active Cl absorption, Active K secretion, active & passive secretion of HCO3
Active Na absorption, Passive Cl absorption, Passive K secretion, active & passive secretion of HCO3

questions.text: What does the 2nd phase of saliva secretion involve?
questions.solution:
Salivary secretion is a two-stage operation:

The first stage involves the acini.

The second stage involves the salivary ducts.

First, Na+ is actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and K+ is actively secreted in exchange for Na+. However, there is excess Na+ reabsorption compared with K+ secretion, which creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts. So this negativity causes Cl- to be reabsorbed passively.

Second, HCO3- is secreted by the ductal epithelium into the lumen of the duct. This secretion is partly caused by passive exchange of bicarbonate for Cl- but it may also result partly from an active secretory process.

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting?
a. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles
b. Inspiration against closed glottis
c. LES opens and UES opens
d. Reverse peristalsis in small intestine
The image shows membrane potential during action potential. The region marked as D-E is due to?
questions.solution:
The Region marked as D-E refers to the repolarization phase which occurs due to efflux of potassium ions (K+).

Different phases of action potential are:

Resting state - Both sodium and potassium voltage-gated channels are closed. The membrane is said to be "polarized" during this stage because of the -70 millivolts negative membrane potential that is present.

Depolarization phase - Sodium channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus resulting in influx of sodium ions. The membrane reaches threshold potential. Sodium influx leads to opening of more sodium channels due to positive feedback leading to rapid depolarization.

Repolarization phase - Sodium channels close and potassium channels open leading to K+ efflux resulting in repolarization.

After Hyperpolarization phase - Slow efflux of K+ continues even after the resting membrane potential is reached resulting in a prolonged phase of hyperpolarization.

At last both channels are closed and the membrane returns to Resting Membrane Potential (RMP).

questions.text: Normal insensible water loss per day?
questions.solution:
Insensible water loss through the respiratory tract normally averages about 300 to 400 ml/day. Insensible water loss through the skin occurs independently of sweating and is present even in people who do not have sweat glands.

The average water loss by diffusion through the skin is about 300 to 400 ml/day.

The normal Insensible water loss is about 700 ml/day or 50 ml/hour.

questions.text: Value of oncotic pressure of tissue-oncotic pressure?
questions.solution:
• The normal tissue oncotic pressure refers to the interstitial osmotic pressure.
  • The oncotic pressure is the amount of osmotic pressure exerted due to plasma proteins like albumin.
  • The interstitial osmotic pressure is different for each organ which depends upon the level of protein components.
  • In most cases it is negligible but the value can be as high as 5 mm Hg in the brain. The values are also positive in the organs like kidneys and liver.
